description: From Middle French revenge, a derivation from revenger, from Old French revengier (possibly influenced by Old Occitan revènge (“revenge, comeback”), from Old Occitan revenir (“to come back”)), a variant of Middle French revancher, from Old French revenchier. The variants Old French vengier (whence French venger) and Old French venchier are both descended from Latin vindicō, with stress-conditioned different parallel development in the inflectional forms. Compare avenge and vengeance.

entries.meaning: Any form of personal, retaliatory action against an individual, institution, or group for some alleged or perceived harm or injustice.
examples: Synonyms: payback, wreak; see also Thesaurus:revenge
When I left my wife, she tried to set fire to the house in revenge.

entries.meaning: A win by a previous loser.

verbs.description: revenge (third-person singular simple present revenges, present participle revenging, simple past and past participle revenged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take revenge for (a particular harmful action) or on behalf of (its victim); to avenge.
examples: Arsenal revenged their loss to Manchester United last time with a 5–0 drubbing this time.

entries.meaning: (transitive, reflexive) To take one's revenge (on or upon someone).
(intransitive, archaic) To take vengeance; to revenge itself.
